summary: One leaf and two strips of a second leaf from a Worcester cartulary, a portion of which is preserved in Nero E. i, fols 181-84. Old English text appears on the recto, column 1, lines 1-15, and both recto and verso of the two strips. The Latin and Old English contents of these fragments (British Library Catalogue) are printed in Stevenson (1911, pp. 199-212).

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: syþþan a oþ his daga ende gode gefultimendum :-

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Continues from BL Cotton Nero, E. i. part 2, Item 7.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Sawyer 1432, dated 822Ã—823. 'Memorandum concerning King Ceolwulf's request for land at Bromsgrove, Worcster, from Bishop Heahberht and his community, and a consequent attempt by Wulfheard to obtain possession of Inkberrow, Worcester' (Sawyer and Keynes 2013).

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): Flædanbyrig Apostolus paulus de extremo iudicio domini manifestissime loquens ita refert.

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: Explicit (Latin): Ego berhtred. Ego oftfor episcopus donationem quam a rege accepi propria manu subnoto.

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: Explicit (Latin): Æþelric. æþelƿard æþelbriht. omuling. abbas. hi sunt confirmatores et testes huiusce donationis.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): In nomine dei excelsi qui est spes omnium finium terre. et in mari longe.

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: Explicit (Latin): Ego mucel dux. Ego ceolfƿulf consensi.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): Ego etiam cenulf rex merciorum eodem honorabili episcopo deneberhto et eius familiæ ƿeogornensis æcclesiæ post uite meæ do terram.

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: Explicit (Latin): Si uero quod non optamus aliquis hoc in aliquo frangere uel minuere temptauerit. sciat se alientum a deo in die magno. nisi ante hic correctus cum satisfactione. emendauerit et ad dignam penitentiam uenerit.

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): In nomine imnipotentis dei et domini nostri iesu christi qui uiuit et regnat in saecula.

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: Explicit (Latin): Signum eadboldi principis. Signum eadboldi ducis.

notes.head: Rubric
notes.body: Rubric (initial): Stoltun. and ƿassaburna. and kineburhtun and tateringtun and codeswæl

notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: Incipit (Latin): Alto etiam agio deo nostro ac sanctæ ac gloriose trinitati uirtus honor et potesta sit in euum.

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: Explicit (Latin): Ego kineberht dux Ego sigered dux

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Continues to BL Cotton Nero, E. i. part 2, Item 8.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Fragmentary, only few words. Sawyer 1446, dated 903. 'Settlement of a dispute between Wærferth, bishop, and Eadnoth, concerning land at Sodbury, Gloucs' (Sawyer and Keynes 2013).

notes.head: Addition
notes.body: ... ndan gen.. |.. STOCE. ÆÐEL.. |.. þegn clericus... |

notes.head: Text Language
notes.body: Latin with English and English bounds.

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Fragmentary, only few words. Sawyer 1317, dated 969. Oswald, bishop, to Æthelweard, his minister; lease, for three lives, of 2 hides (mansae) at Stoke Bishop, Gloucs., with reversion to the bishopric (Sawyer and Keynes 2013).

notes.head: Explicit
notes.body: ... æs croftes þærto.. |.. on þæt ilce gerad..

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Fragmentary. Sawyer 1362, dated 990. 'Oswald, archbishop, to Æthelmær, his man; lease, for three lives, of 1 hide at Compton Greenfield and 1 at Marsh, Gloucs., in return for 2 pounds of silver and livestock, with postscript granting the worthig at Brynes hamme which Æthelm owned. Bounds of Marsh' (Sawyer and Keynes 2013). [xx]

objectDesc.extent:
436 mm x 292-95 mm (dimensions of leaf - size of leaf, trimmed).
378-82 mm x 13-14 mm (dimensions of all - size of strips).
objectDesc.condition: The leaf, which was cut in half for a binding, is now taped together. Two strips are from a single leaf. The fragments are kept in a wooden frame between two sheets of plastic.

layoutDesc.summary: The outer pricking is visible. The large capital letters are placed in the double lines on the left side of the writing space.

objectDesc.note: Double columns, 44 lines. The original position of the leaf was between fols 182 and 183 of Nero E. i, part 2. The fragments have an 'unusually large format' (Webster and Backhouse 1991, p. 123), suggesting that they formed part of a cartulary which was written and inserted into a Bible, perhaps the one reported to have been given to Worcester by King Offa (Atkins and Ker 1944, pp. 77-79).

handDesc.summary: The scribe makes a clear distinction between English and Latin in terms of script. Round and compact.

characters.note: • Ã¦ has e higher than a.
Insular d is round-backed and its ascender is horizontal.
Insular f; the end of the descender curves to the left.
Larger n is used at the end of the line to fill in the space.
Insular s is used, as well as long s, which has an extended head. The descender of long s sometimes stops on the writing line.
Ã° has a tall ascender, and its cross bar is mostly a straight horizontal line, which extends only to the right of the ascender. The cross-bar sometimes curls downwards at the right end.
y is dotted, and its descender extends to theleft under the previous letter.
descenders are straight and shorter than the height of the body of the letter and slightly curve to the left at the very end.
Ë¥ mark is high, and extends to the length of the descender. The horizontal head is straight or slightly curved backward.
The cross-bar of Ã¾ for the abbreviation of Ã¾Ã¦t is a straight horizontal line, which extends only to the right of the ascender.
macrons are straight horizontal lines, and the ends sometimes curls upwards. The same for the cross bar of Æ€.

decoration: Some rubrics are also in red.
additions: The seventeenth-century handwriting on the leaf might be that of the naturalist Francis Willoughby (1635-72), who is suggested to have rescued the leaf from a bundle of estate documents at Wollaton Hall (Stevenson 1911, p. 197).

history.origin: Presumed to have been written at Worcester (British Library Catalogue).
history.provenance:
Appears to have remained in Worcester.

The Willoughby family (of Middleton Hall) acquired documents from Worcester when it was dissolved in 1540.

The fragments were used in the binding of the 'Colpyt Book from the Natyvitie of Our Lorde in anno regni Regis Edwardi Sexti secundo' at Middleton Hall and the leaf was discovered in a bundle of estate documents at Wollaton Hall, one of the seats of the Willoughby family.

The trace of the binding is clearly visible. The leaf was cut in half and was used as pastedowns of covers. The two strips were probably used on the spine of the book.
history.acquisition: It was acquired from Lord Middleton by the British Library with the aid of a contribution from Neil Ker.

admin: Manuscript described by Takako Kato with the assistance of Hollie Morgan (2010; 2013).
